content.text: Define gravitational potential at a point
The radius of Artemis is \(4800\mathrm{km}\)
Determine the value of \(\phi\) on the surface of Artemis
Show that the mass of Artemis is \(2.55 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\)
Calculate the gravitational field strength \(g\) on the surface of Artemis

A satellite is in an orbit at a fixed position above a point on the surface of Artemis. The satellite is located above the equator of Artemis at a height above the surface where the gravitational potential is \(-0.65 \times 10^{7} \text{Jkg}^{-1}\)
Calculate the period, in hours, of rotation of Artemis
period = .........hours
Artemis is a spherical planet that may be assumed to be isolated in space. The variation with distance \(x\) from the centre of Artemis of the gravitational potential \(\phi\) is shown in Fig. 1.1
State one similarity and one difference between gravitational potential due to a point mass and electric potential due to a point charge
similarity
difference
State what is meant by an ideal gas
Show that the helium gas behaves as an ideal gas
The first law of thermodynamics may be expressed as
Use the first law of thermodynamics to explain why the temperature of the helium gas increases
The average translational kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by
where \(k\) is the Boltzmann constant and \(T\) is the thermodynamic temperature
Calculate the change in the total kinetic energy of the molecules of the helium gas
change in kinetic energy = .........J

A fixed amount of helium gas is sealed in a container. The helium gas has a pressure of \(1.10 \times 10^{5} \text{ Pa}\), and a volume of \(540 \text{ cm}^3\) at a temperature of \(27^{\circ} \text{C}\)

The volume of the container is rapidly decreased to \(30.0 \text{ cm}^3\). The pressure of the helium gas increases to \(6.70 \times 10^6 \text{ Pa}\) and its temperature increases to \(742^\circ \text{C}\), as illustrated in Fig. 2.1
No thermal energy enters or leaves the helium gas during this process

The mass of nitrogen gas in another container is \(24.0 \text{g}\) at a temperature of \(27^{\circ} \text{C}\). The gas is cooled to its boiling point of \(-196^{\circ} \text{C}\). Assume all the gas condenses to a liquid
For this change the specific heat capacity of nitrogen gas is \(1.04 \text{kJ} \text{kg}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1}\)
The specific latent heat of vaporisation of nitrogen is \(199 \text{kJ} \text{kg}^{-1}\)
Determine the thermal energy, in kJ, removed from the nitrogen gas
energy = .........kJ
The kinetic energy, the potential energy and the total energy of the oscillations are each represented by one of the lines P, Q and R
State the energy that is represented by each of the lines P, Q and R
P
Q
R
The object has a mass of \(130\mathrm{g}\)
Determine the period of the oscillations
period = .........s
State the cause of damping

A light card is attached to the object. The object is displaced with the same initial amplitude and then released. During each complete oscillation the total energy of the system decreases by \(8.0\%\) of the total energy at the start of that oscillation
Determine the decrease in total energy, in mJ, of the system by the end of the first 6 complete oscillations
energy lost = .........mJ
State, with a reason, the type of damping that the card introduces into the system
An object is suspended from a vertical spring as shown in Fig. 3.1
The object is displaced vertically and then released so that it oscillates, undergoing simple harmonic motion
Fig. 3.2 shows the variation with displacement \(x\) of the energy \(E\) of the oscillations
State Coulomb's law
On Fig. 4.2, draw and label all the forces acting on sphere Y
Determine the mass of sphere Y
Calculate the total electric potential energy stored between X and Y
energy = .........J
A charged sphere X is supported on an insulating stand. A second charged sphere Y is suspended by an insulating thread so that sphere Y is in equilibrium at the position shown in Fig. 4.1
The charge on sphere X is \(+96 \text{nC}\) and the charge on sphere Y is \(+64 \text{nC}\)
Assume that the spheres behave as point charges
The length of the thread is \(1.2 \text{m}\) and the centres of sphere X and sphere Y are separated horizontally by a distance of \(0.080 \text{m}\)
State the direction of the electric force on the electron when between the plates
Determine the magnitude of the force acting on the electron due to the electric field
Explain why the electron does **not** follow a circular path
An electron enters the region between two parallel plates P and Q, that are separated by a distance of \(18\mathrm{mm}\), as shown in Fig. 4.3
The space between the plates is a vacuum
The potential difference between the plates is \(250\mathrm{V}.\) The electric field may be assumed to be uniform in the region between the plates and zero outside this region
Show that the capacitance of the capacitor is \(1.5 \mu \mathrm{F}\)
Determine the resistance of R
resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
Calculate the energy stored in the capacitor at time \(t = 0\)
energy = .........J
A second identical resistor is now connected in parallel with R

The switch is initially in position S. When the capacitor is fully charged, the switch is moved to position T so that the capacitor discharges. At time \(t\) after the switch is moved the charge on the capacitor is Q
On Fig. 5.2, sketch a line to show the variation of \(\ln (Q / \mu \mathrm{C})\) with \(t\) between time \(t = 0\) and time \(t = 5.0 \text{s}\)
A capacitor, a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(12\mathrm{V}\), a resistor R and a two-way switch are connected in the circuit shown in Fig. 5.1

The switch is initially in position S. When the capacitor is fully charged, the switch is moved to position T so that the capacitor discharges. At time \(t\) after the switch is moved the charge on the capacitor is \(Q\)
The variation with \(t\) of \(\ln (Q / \mu \mathrm{C})\) is shown in Fig. 5.2
A Hall probe is placed in a magnetic field. The Hall voltage is zero. The Hall probe is rotated to a new position in the magnetic field. The Hall voltage is now maximum
Explain these observations
State the meaning of \(n\)
Explain why a Hall probe is made from silicon rather than copper
The formula for calculating the Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) as measured by a Hall probe is
Table 6.1 shows the value of \(n\) for two materials
A Hall probe gives a maximum reading of \(24 \text{mV}\) when placed in a uniform magnetic field of flux density \(32 \text{mT}\)

The same Hall probe is then placed in a magnetic field of fixed direction and varying flux density. The Hall probe is in a fixed position so that the angle between the Hall probe and the magnetic field is the same as when the Hall voltage was \(24 \text{mV}\)
The variation of the reading \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) on the Hall probe with time \(t\) from time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = 8.6 \text{s}\) is shown in Fig. 6.1
A coil with 780 turns and a diameter of \(3.6 \text{cm}\) is placed in this varying magnetic field. The plane of the coil is perpendicular to the field lines
Calculate the magnitude of the maximum electromotive force (e.m.f.) induced in the coil in the time between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 8.6 \text{s}\)
A beam of white light passes through a cloud of cool gas. The spectrum of the transmitted light is viewed and contains a number of dark lines
Explain why these dark lines occur
Some energy levels for the electron in an isolated hydrogen atom are illustrated in Fig. 7.1
Table 7.1 shows the wavelengths of photons that are emitted in the transitions to \(n = 2\) from the other energy levels shown in Fig. 7.1
The energy associated with the energy level \(n = 2\) is \(-3.40 \text{eV}\)
Complete the equation to show the decay of plutonium-238

parts.label: (i)

content.text: Calculate the initial number \(N_{\mathrm{o}}\) of nuclei of plutonium-238 in the power source

content.text: Determine the initial activity of the source. Give a unit with your answer
Use your answer in **(b)**(ii) to determine the initial power output from the source due to the decay of plutonium-238
power output = .........\(W\)
The space probe will continue to function until the power output from the plutonium in the source decreases to \(65.3\%\) of its initial value
Calculate the time, in years, for which the space probe will function
time = .........years

The power source in a space probe contains \(0.874 \text{kg}\) of plutonium-238. Each nucleus of plutonium-238 that decays emits \(5.59 \text{MeV}\) of energy. The half-life of plutonium-238 is \(87.7\) years

An alternative power source uses energy generated from the radioactive decay of polonium-210. This isotope has a half-life of 0.378 years. The mass of the isotope needed for the same initial power output as in (b) is 3.37 g
Suggest one advantage and one disadvantage of using polonium-210 as the source of energy
advantage
disadvantage
Plutonium-238 ( \(^{238}_{94}\mathrm{Pu})\) is unstable and undergoes alpha decay

content.text: \(\omega .\)
An alternating voltage \(V\) varies with time \(t\) according to
The voltage is applied to an ultrasound probe
The root-mean-square (r.m.s.) voltage is \(66\mathrm{V}.\) The frequency of the ultrasound generated by the probe is \(4.3\mathrm{MHz}\)
Determine the values of
Determine the unit for the specific acoustic impedance values shown in Table 9.1
Calculate the density of soft tissue
density = .........\(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m}^{-3}\)
Use data from Table 9.1 to explain why ultrasound cannot be used to produce an image inside an air-filled cavity such as the lungs
Table 9.1 contains information about air and soft tissue
Ultrasound is used to produce diagnostic information about internal body structures
A student observes different stars from the Earth
Give two reasons why some stars appear brighter than others
State what is meant by a standard candle
Show that the speed of the star relative to the Earth is \(2.1 \times 10^{6} \text{m s}^{-1}\)
Calculate the distance to the star
The Hubble constant is \(2.3 \times 10^{-18} \text{s}^{-1}\)
distance = .........m
State and explain what can be concluded about the Universe based on this change in observed wavelength

A spectral line from a star within a galaxy is observed to have a wavelength of \(660.9 \text{nm}\). The same spectral line measured in the laboratory is observed to have a wavelength of \(656.3 \text{nm}\)
